I once heard that in the countries of lions, a person obtained a maá¹‡i jewel as big as a human knee, which was so extraordinary that it was rarely seen in the world, and offered it to the king.
After the king obtained the jewel, he looked at it carefully and spoke a verse, saying:
The ancient kings accumulated treasures seeking fame,
Gathering guests and showing off their treasures, priding themselves.
When they relinquished their positions and died, they abandoned their treasures and went alone,
Only their good and evil karma followed their bodies and did not leave them.
It is like bees making honey, others obtain it but they themselves do not get it,
Wealth and treasures are also like this, benefiting others but not following oneself.
In the past, kings of various countries were deceived by treasures,
Accumulating and waiting for others, not a single one followed them.
I will now do it myself, and must make the treasure follow me.
Only in the field of blessings of the Buddha, create various merits and virtues,
Following me to the next world, the good rewards will not perish.
When one is about to die, everything will be abandoned,
The entire palace, relatives and loved ones, ministers and brave generals,
Mourning and sending off the deceased, to the cemetery then returning home.
Elephants, horses, precious carriages, treasures and storehouses,
People, cities and towns, gardens and delightful places,
Suddenly leaving alone, not a single follower.

Having spoken this verse, the king went to the stupa and placed the precious pearl on top of the stupa pole. It shone brightly like a large star, illuminating the king's palace like the sun, its radiance twice as bright as usual.
The pearl's light was always like this every day, but one day it suddenly lost its color and luster. The king wondered about this and sent someone to investigate.

When they arrived, they did not see the precious pearl, but only saw blood flowing on the ground below the pole. They followed the trail of blood to the Khadali Grove, and before reaching the grove, they saw the person who had stolen the pearl hiding in the trees.
When the person who had stolen the pearl took the pearl, they fell from the pole and broke their thigh, hence the blood. They immediately seized the person and brought them before the king.
When the king first saw them, he was very angry, but upon seeing their injuries, he felt pity. He looked at them with compassion and said:
Alas, man!
You are extremely foolish, stealing the Buddha's precious pearl. In the future, you will certainly fall into a bad realm.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
Alas, how foolish and ignorant! Committing great evil,
Like a person who fears being beaten with a stick, yet returns to accept being beheaded.
Fearing the suffering of poverty, giving rise to this crazy and foolish idea,
Not enduring a little poverty, enduring endless misfortune for a long time.
At that time, a minister heard this verse and said to the king:
As the king has said, it is true and not false.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
The stupa is a treasure among humans. The foolish one rashly steals it.
This person will not encounter the Three Jewels for countless eons.
As in the past, there was a person who, out of faithful joy,
Used a Sumana flower from his ear to offer to the Buddha's stupa.
For a hundred koá¹­Ä«s of eons in the human and heavenly realms, he greatly enjoyed great happiness.
The ten-powered World-Honored One's stÅ«pa, stealing treasures to build for oneself,
Because of this karmic cause, one sinks into hell.
Another minister harbored resentment and said:
Such a foolish person's crimes are already evident, why bother to scold him?
It is appropriate to inflict the death penalty.
The king told the minister:
Do not speak like this!
Since that person is already dead, why kill him again?
When a person falls to the ground, they should be helped up.
At that time, the king spoke a verse, saying:
This person has already ruined his practice, he should be quickly rescued,
I will bestow wealth and treasures, causing him to repent and cultivate merit,
Enabling him to escape, from the great suffering and difficulty in the future.
I will give him money and property, causing him to make offerings to the Buddha,
If he does not turn to the Buddha, his offenses will never be extinguished.
Just as a person falls to the ground because of the earth, they are supported and can get up again,
Because of the Buddha, I incurred offenses, and also because of the Buddha, they are extinguished.
At that time, the king immediately bestowed a great deal of wealth and instructed him to make various merits at the Buddha's side.
At that time, the thief then had this thought:
Now, the great king!
If it were not for the person who is disciplined within the Buddha's teachings, my crime would have been calculated and I would have been executed.
This king is able to pardon me, and is truly a great man who has forgiven my grave offense.
The ÅšÄkya TathÄgata is truly extraordinary, as he is able to discipline and transform the king of a heretical view country to do such things.
Having said this, he returned to the stÅ«pa and crawled towards the temple, joining his palms in reverence and saying:

The Greatly Compassionate World-Honored One, the True Savior of the World, although he has entered nirvÄá¹‡a, is still able to use his life to bestow relief upon me. The world all calls him the True Savior, his fame is universally renowned throughout all worlds, and now he has saved my life. Therefore, the name True Savior is not falsely established.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
The world calls him the True Savior, this name is truly not false.
I am now saved and rescued, knowing the true meaning of the True Savior.
The world is all ablaze, with much heat and distress,
The moon of compassion and coolness shines, removing the suffering of heat and distress.
When the Tathagata was in the world, at the place of the ghost in the wilderness,
He rescued the elder Shouleng, this matter is not difficult.
Now, after his nirvana, in the remaining Dharma he saves from danger and hardship,
Causing me to escape from suffering and distress, this is very difficult indeed.
How is it that the craftsmen of the world, with marvelous skill, harmonize with the sage's mind,
Painting an image with the right hand raised, showing the comforting appearance,
Those who are frightened see it and are still able to remove fear,
How much more so when the Buddha was in the world, saving many with great compassion,
May the image save me.
Furthermore, one who is content, even if having wealth, does not cherish it in the mind, and can still be called content.
I once heard that there was an upÄsaka. At that time, the upÄsaka had a friend who believed in the brÄhmaá¹‡a teachings.

At that time, the friend who believed well in the brÄhmaá¹‡as, wearing tattered clothes and practicing austerities, scorched his body with the five heats, always ate poor food and slept in filth, and then called the upÄsaka, saying:
You can come here and observe the brÄhmaá¹‡as. Have you ever seen such a person of pure body, self-mortification, lofty conduct, few desires, and contentment?
The upÄsaka said:
Such lofty conduct can deceive you.
Then he went with his friend to ask the brÄhmaá¹‡a:
What do you seek by practicing austerities now?
The brÄhmaá¹‡a said:
I now practice austerities, wishing to become a king.
At that time, the upÄsaka said to his friend:

This person is now seeking the entire earth, treasuries, and precious treasures. He wants to kill and enjoy himself, indulge in delicious flavors, have palace ladies and servants, enjoy female beauty, and amuse himself with various kinds of music.

Although he is a great minister and elder with various wealth and treasures, he is not satisfied. He now wants to seek the entire earth, people, and precious treasures. How can he be called one of few desires?
You only see his physical practice of austerities and consider him to have few desires. You do not know that what this person seeks is insatiable, and you call it having few desires.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
So-called few desires do not necessarily mean bad clothes and food,
Nor do they mean lacking various necessities and calling it few desires.
This person now has a mind like a great river or sea,
Greedy and insatiable. How can he be called one of few desires?
Now cultivating these ascetic practices, for the sake of craving the five desires,
This person is truly deceitful, falsely displaying the appearance of few desires,
For the sake of greed, he torments himself, he is not truly one of few desires.
Having spoken this verse, the upÄsaka further said:
Now this person is replete with greed, anger, and delusion, and has not the slightest bit of the practice of sages and saints.
Therefore, one should know that having few desires does not lie in having money or many precious things.
How can this be known?
Like King BimbisÄra who was wealthy with a country, elephants, horses, and the seven treasures, he was still called one of few desires.
Why is this?

Although he had wealth and treasures, his mind was not attached to them, and he delighted in the noble path. For this reason, although he was wealthy with the seven treasures overflowing, his mind had no desire and was called having few desires.
Although without wealth and treasures, desiring and seeking without satiation, one cannot be called one of few desires and contentment.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
If one considers going naked and fasting, like the Jains,
And engaging in various austerities, to be the practice of asceticism;
Then hungry ghosts, animals, and the poor and suffering,
Who are in difficult circumstances, should also be called ascetics.
That person is also like this, merely exhausting themselves,
Though their body may engage in ascetic practices, their mind harbors attachment,
Desiring and seeking without satisfaction, they are not called one of few desires.
Even if one possesses many things, if the mind is unstained and attached,
Cultivating the practice of the noble path, this is called having few desires.
It is like farmers who plant seeds in the fields,
Desiring to harvest many fruits, they are not called one of few desires.
The body is like a foul-smelling wound, requiring various necessities,
Seeking the path with the mind, this is called one of few desires.
To treat evil boils and sores, one should accept only the necessities of life,
And not crave for future existence - this is truly called having few desires.
The mind and thoughts are not deceitful, and one does not seek fame and profit,
Although one may have the necessities of life, one's fame and virtues are genuine,
If one is able to do such things, this is truly having few desires.
(6) Furthermore, even if one observes the precepts for the sake of the pleasures of humans and gods, this is called breaking the precepts.

I once heard that there was a Å›ramaá¹‡a who, together with a brÄhman, was staying in a secluded forest during the summer retreat. The Å›ramaá¹‡a would often go back and forth to the brÄhman's place, treating him neither too familiarly nor too distantly, but just right.
Why is this?
If he were too familiar with him, he feared he would give rise to arrogance; if he were too distant, he feared he would be disliked.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
When a stick is placed in the sun, whether standing or lying down, it casts no shadow,
Those who hold staffs and lean on them, their shadows are long and drawn out.
That person is also like this, intimacy and distance should be moderate,
Allowing gradual familiarity, then explain the Dharma for them.
This brahmin has no wisdom, does not distinguish between wise and foolish, and serves with extreme hardship, therefore I should neither be intimate with him nor distant.
Why is this?
Serving a foolish person is suffering, not understanding how to serve is also called suffering.
Using various skillful means, they became acquainted, gradually gained each other's trust, and were able to converse.
At that time the bhiká¹£u asked the brahmin:
Why do you now raise your hands towards the sun, lie on ashes and dirt, go naked, eat grass, stand on tiptoe day and night without lying down, and practice this suffering for what you seek?
The brahmin replied:
I seek to be a king.
This brahmin, after a short time, fell ill and went to ask a doctor for a cure.
The doctor said to him:
You should eat meat.
Then the brahmin said to the bhiká¹£u:
You can go to the donor's house for me and beg for some meat to cure my illness.
At that time, the bhiká¹£u thought like this:
Now is the right time to transform him.
Having thought this, he transformed into a sheep and tied it to his side. The brahmin asked the bhiká¹£u:
Where is the meat you begged for now?
The bhiká¹£u replied:
The sheep is the meat.
The brahmin became very angry and said:
Would I rather kill a sheep and eat its meat?
Then the bhiká¹£u spoke a verse in reply:
You now pity a single sheep and still do not want to kill it,
Later, if you become a king, you will kill countless cows, sheep, pigs,
Chickens, dogs, and wild animals,
While you sit on your throne, the cooks will prepare food for you.
When you become angry, you will say to cut off their heads,
Or to cut off their hands and feet, and sometimes to gouge out their eyes.
You now pity a single sheep, but you are about to kill many,
If you truly have compassion, you should abandon your desire to be king.
Like a person about to be executed, fearing the pain, drinks alcohol,
The flower garden is in full bloom, but a fierce fire is about to burn it.
Also, like being chained in gold, although beautiful, it can bind,
The position of king is also like this, always with a fearful mind.
The powerful attendants, adorned with precious treasures,
Do not see the faults that will come later, ordinary people greedily desire and seek.
Having committed various evils, one falls into the three evil paths,
Like a moth greedy for the color of fire, throwing oneself into it and burning to death.
Although there are the pleasures of the five desires, with fame heard everywhere,
One always has much fear, with suffering and worry extremely deep.
It is like holding a poisonous snake, or carrying a torch against the wind,
If one does not let go, danger will come, just like the suffering of facing death.
When the king goes out to play, he wears a heavenly crown on his head,
Adorned with various treasures, wearing the most wonderful and magnificent clothes,
Riding famous horses and jeweled carriages, he goes out on excursions,
Followed by hundreds of thousands on the road, with extremely powerful authority.
If there are enemies, he adorns his body with jeweled armor,
If victorious, he kills many; if defeated, he loses his life.
Smearing his body with wonderful fragrances, wearing clothes perfumed with incense,
The various delicacies they eat, with a hundred flavors to satisfy their mouths,
All their needs are met according to their wishes, with none who goes against them,
Whether walking, coming, sitting, or lying down, every movement is done with suspicion and fear.
Even close friends are not trusted, even though they may be close friends,
They always have a fearful mind, how can this be called happiness?ğŸ”½Like a fish swallowing a baited hook, like a sharp knife smeared with honey,
Also like a net or snare, fish and beasts greedy for its flavor,
Not seeing the suffering and harm that will come later, the noble and wealthy are also like this,
In the end they will suffer the torments of hell, the walls and fences of hell,
The house and ground are all ablaze, the sinners are within,
The fire comes out and burns their bodies, the suffering they receive is immeasurable.
You should contemplate for yourself, the happiness you create is little,
The many sufferings and harms are very great, therefore you should contemplate suffering.
Do not seek noble self-mastery, abandon your mind of seeking and wishing,
Only seek liberation, and all suffering will be eliminated.
When the brÄhmaá¹‡a heard these verses, he remained silent and did not reply. He joined his palms towards the bhiká¹£u and said:
Venerable One!
You have eloquence and have enlightened my mind. Even if I were to obtain the king of the thirty-three heavens, I would not find it sweet or enjoyable.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
With skillful means and a good mind, clear wisdom can observe,
For me, remove the wrong wishes, and show the path of true reality.
Good friends should be like this, praised by the world,
One should always be close to such friends, without the affliction of disputes and troubles.
They guide my mind and thoughts well, turning away from wrong and entering the right path,
Showing me the characteristics of good and evil, enabling me to attain liberation.

Furthermore, those who rely on the wrong path will suffer from various afflictions, while those who cultivate the right path will increase their faith and reputation. The wise should observe what is right and wrong.
I once heard that there was a person who practiced austerities by the side of the road. If there were people, he would lie on thorns; if there were no people, he would live elsewhere.
Someone saw him and said:
You can now slowly lie on the thorns, why must you let your body be so severely injured?
This person, upon hearing this, became very angry and threw himself onto the thorns, even more severely than before.
At that time, there was an upÄsaka standing by his side. The ascetic saw him and shook himself, becoming even more severe.
The upÄsaka then said to him:
Previously you only used small thorns, but now you are using the thorns of anger to pierce yourself.
The wounds from the previous pricks were very shallow, but the pricks of greed and hatred were deeply penetrating.

Lying on thorn pricks, the suffering lasts only one lifetime, but the suffering of the pricks of greed and hatred extends to countless bodies. Pricking oneself with thorns, this wound is easily healed, but the wound of the pricks of greed and hatred is not cured for eons. Therefore, one should quickly remove the deeply poisonous thorns.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
You should now diligently pull out the deeply poisonous thorns in your heart,
You should use the sharp sword of wisdom to cut off the thorns of greed and hatred.
Greed and hatred deeply afflict people, and cannot be removed for generations,
Foolish and small, with various wrong views, they do not recognize the true and correct path.
Torturing the body, lying on thorn pricks, using suffering to try to escape suffering,
When people see someone lying on thorn pricks, none of them do not flee far away.
Only you, in this suffering, embrace it and do not let go,
When I see such things, I then know there is right and wrong.
Therefore, I take refuge in the World-Honored One with the ten powers,
The one with great compassion who uproots the suffering of the masses and reveals the right path,
Leading those who have entered the wrong paths with the eightfold right path.
The non-Buddhist paths and wrong views are deceived by suffering,
Deeply attached to suffering, they transmigrate endlessly.
Those with wisdom, upon seeing this, double their faith,
The non-Buddhists are extremely deluded, thinking that ending suffering leads to liberation.
The great sage who transcends the world says that all necessary conditions are complete,
One can cultivate the eightfold right path, and through cultivating the path, one attains liberation.
Therefore, know that attaining liberation brings happiness,
Unlike the non-Buddhists, who attain nirvana through suffering.
Based on the mind, one creates various good and evil karma,
You should subdue the mind and thoughts, why torment the body in vain?
The body is a mass of afflictions, falsely cultivating various hardships,
For one who cultivates the path through suffering, hell should be the path.
But in this hell, there is cutting, slicing, excrement and urine,
Blazing, burning, and so forth, fully experiencing various sufferings.
Although they experience various sufferings, they cannot be called practitioners of austerities,
Wisdom removes the defilements of the three karmas, and all impurities are eliminated.
The teachings of Shakyamuni Buddha teach all people,
To seek the heavenly nectar, and also proclaim the stilling and contemplation,
And also adorn wisdom, this is called true austerity.
What is the use of vainly exhausting the body?
Creating useless suffering, this suffering is very long, deep, and vast, without bounds.
It is like having an evil child who does not receive filial support,
But only commits various offenses, and thus experiences various sufferings.
At that time, the non-Buddhist said:
The sages who practice austerities can also be reborn in the heavens.
The upÄsaka replied in verse:
The sages are reborn in the heavens, not because of lying on thorns,
But because of giving, precepts, and true speech, they can be reborn in the heavens.
Although you practice austerities, they are of no benefit at all.
It is like a farmer in spring who does not plant seeds,
In autumn there will be no harvest to reap.
You are also like this, not planting the seeds of good roots,
But only practicing austerities, in the end you will gain nothing.
Those who wish to cultivate the Way should rely on this body,
With delicious food and drink, to nourish the body and life.
When vitality and strength are abundant, one can cultivate precepts, concentration, and wisdom,
Abstaining from food, I am very hungry and thirsty, with body and mind both disturbed and troubled.
Not allowing the mind to be focused and settled, how can I attain the holy fruits?
Although I may eat fine food, I do not crave delicious flavors,
But only for precepts, true speech, giving, patience, and meditation,
These are the seeds that can obtain good karmic fruits.
Although the body may experience hunger and thirst, the mind still hopes for delicious flavors,
Even when the cause is still not sweet, how much less can it obtain delicious fruits?
If there is a mind of destruction and harm, causing others to give rise to fear,
If one can remove the mind of destruction and harm and give fearlessness to others,
This is called practicing the Dharma.
If one further gives rise to destruction and harm, it is called non-Dharma.
In the end, there is no intention to harm others, because of the mind of non-harming,
There is no harm to others, if one gives rise to a greatly compassionate mind,
Then one obtains a greatly wholesome fruit.
Although you practice fasting, hungry and thirsty, sleeping, it is also useless.
The non-Buddhist said this:
Just as when you give rise to a compassionate mind, it may not necessarily benefit, but you obtain great rewards.
Fasting and sleeping, the matter is also like this,
Although it does not benefit others, you also obtain good results.
The upÄsaka replied:
A compassionate mind removes anger and harm. Because it removes anger and harm, it can obtain good results.
Your method of practicing austerities increases anger,
So you give rise to evil deeds of body and speech. How can you obtain good results?
A compassionate mind is not like this. When you give rise to a compassionate mind,
You can remove anger and harm.
Because there is no anger and harm, you give rise to good deeds of body and speech.
How can useless and painful practices be the same as the kindness of compassion?
It is like the lion's roar, with no one daring to oppose it.
It is the same with this matter, with all the non-Buddhists,
No one dares to confront it.
Expounding the Dharma to defeat the non-Buddhists, they remain silent without a response.
Furthermore, bodily and verbal actions cannot be independent, they must be based on the mind.

Then he spoke a verse, saying:

The lion is a metaphor for a wise person who is able to seek the source and extinguish afflictions.

At that time, the brÄhmaá¹‡a, his words exhausted and his principles defeated, was unable to retaliate,

(9) Furthermore, desire is like a lump of meat that many birds compete for. A wise person deeply understands the troubles of wealth and does not crave it.

I once heard that in the country of Xiupo, there was a bhiká¹£u who saw a buried treasure in a collapsed wall, a large copper urn full of gold coins. He took a poor upÄsaka and showed him the place, saying:

The upÄsaka asked the bhiká¹£u:

The bhiká¹£u replied:

The upÄsaka said:

Now listen well!

If you take this treasure and it is heard by the king, you will either die, be exiled, or be imprisoned. The suffering from this will be innumerable.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
I have seen this treasure for a very long time,
This jewel is poisonous and harmful, more so than a black poisonous snake.
Therefore, I have no greedy thoughts towards this jewel at all,
Regarding it as a poisonous snake, not thinking of it as a precious treasure.
Being bound, exiled, punished, or even reaching death,
All kinds of disasters, all arise from this jewel.
Causing various kinds of suffering, the harm is extremely frightening,
Therefore, I do not give rise to thoughts of greed or intimacy towards the jewel.
Beings are deluded and attached to jewels, regarding them as precious playthings,
